private_information: You are responsible for formalizing the symbolic dynamics of the world as action schemas, predicates, and objects.

You must preserve the exact action names and argument orders: paltry(object_0 object_1 object_2), sip(object_0 object_1 object_2), clip(object_0 object_1 object_2), wretched(object_0 object_1 object_2 object_3), memory(object_0 object_1 object_2), tightfisted(object_0 object_1 object_2).
You should output a compact machine-readable JSON specification with keys: predicates, actions, each action containing name, parameters, preconditions, add_effects, del_effects, and no PDDL.
Do not invent new predicates or actions; do not drop any given predicate.
domain_modeler.goal: Deliver a clean symbolic model of predicates and actions that matches the human description and is ready for integration into a PDDL domain by the orchestrator.

private_information: You are responsible for building grounded problem instances from the human statements.
Produce two structured instances: scenario_A (which includes a provided plan) and scenario_B (no plan provided).
Output a machine-readable JSON with keys per scenario: objects, init (list of grounded facts), goal (list of grounded facts); do not emit PDDL.
scenario_curator.goal: Produce grounded initial states and goals for scenario_A and scenario_B that exactly reflect the human statements.

private_information: You parse and analyze the human-provided plan for scenario_A only.

Return a machine-readable analysis including: ordered steps, per-step preconditions and expected add/del effects based on the domain model, causal links, open preconditions if any, and suggested repairs when a mismatch is detected.
Do not emit PDDL and do not rely on bookkeeping shortcuts such as quota tokens or post-hoc penalties.
plan_analyst.goal: Provide a faithful, checkable analysis of the scenario_A plan that the temporal_auditor can use to validate causal and temporal consistency.

private_information: You audit temporal and causal consistency across the symbolic model and the curated scenarios.
You must eliminate or flag any bookkeeping shortcuts or non-causal constructs (quota tokens, post-hoc penalties, artificial counters, implicit frame assumptions that contradict the model).
Your output is a concise audit report that lists verified invariants, detected inconsistencies, recommended constraint fixes, and a minimal set of clarifications for the orchestrator.
temporal_auditor.goal: Validate that the action preconditions and effects support the scenarios and the provided plan (scenario_A), and deliver a clear audit report to inform the orchestrator.

private_information: You integrate all upstream outputs and produce the final PDDL domain and a single PDDL problem file targeting the FastDownward solver.
Target scenario_B as the final problem to solve.
Ensure compatibility with FastDownward: include :strips and :typing (if you introduce types), avoid unsupported constructs, and keep actions and predicate names faithful to the symbolic spec.
Maintain the exact action names: paltry, sip, clip, wretched, memory, tightfisted, with parameters and effects exactly as specified.
orchestrator.goal: Produce a correct PDDL domain and a single PDDL problem (for scenario_B) so that FastDownward can find a plan to achieve the stated goals.

public_information: Actions available over objects: paltry object_0 object_1 object_2; sip object_0 object_1 object_2; clip object_0 object_1 object_2; wretched object_0 object_1 object_2 object_3; memory object_0 object_1 object_2; tightfisted object_0 object_1 object_2.
paltry preconditions: hand object_0, cats object_1, texture object_2, vase object_0 object_1, next object_1 object_2; effects add: next object_0 object_2; effects del: vase object_0 object_1.
sip preconditions: hand object_0, cats object_1, texture object_2, next object_0 object_2, next object_1 object_2; effects add: vase object_0 object_1; effects del: next object_0 object_2.
clip preconditions: hand object_0, sneeze object_1, texture object_2, next object_1 object_2, next object_0 object_2; effects add: vase object_0 object_1; effects del: next object_0 object_2.

wretched preconditions: sneeze object_0, texture object_1, texture object_2, stupendous object_3, next object_0 object_1, collect object_1 object_3, collect object_2 object_3; effects add: next object_0 object_2; effects del: next object_0 object_1.
memory preconditions: cats object_0, spring object_1, spring object_2, next object_0 object_1; effects add: next object_0 object_2; effects del: next object_0 object_1.
tightfisted preconditions: hand object_0, sneeze object_1, texture object_2, next object_1 object_2, vase object_0 object_1; effects add: next object_0 object_2; effects del: vase object_0 object_1.
Scenario A initial facts and goals are provided under environment.scenarios.scenario_A; Scenario B initial facts and goals are provided under environment.scenarios.scenario_B.

FastDownward compatibility requirement: when emitting PDDL, include :strips and optionally :typing, avoid quantifiers and derived predicates, ensure all objects and facts are grounded and names are consistent.

grounding.system_prompt: You are a world-modeling specialist. Convert the public action descriptions into a concise machine-readable JSON schema with keys: predicates (list of predicate names with arities), actions (list with name, parameters in order, preconditions, add_effects, del_effects). Preserve action names and parameter orders exactly. Do not emit PDDL.
grounding.prompt: Your name is domain_modeler. Use the following public information to produce a clean symbolic specification with no omissions and no extra constructs: {environment->public_information}. Keep actions: paltry, sip, clip, wretched, memory, tightfisted. Parameters correspond to object roles in order and all facts are groundable over environment.init.object_universe. Output only the JSON schema for predicates and actions.

datasets.system_prompt: You curate grounded instances. Build two instances scenario_A and scenario_B as machine-readable JSON blocks containing objects, init, goal, taken from environment.scenarios. Do not emit PDDL.
datasets.prompt: Your name is scenario_curator. Extract the two scenarios exactly as stated in environment.scenarios (no additions). Ensure fact strings are consistent with the domain_modeler predicates. Provide a JSON object with keys scenario_A and scenario_B, each with objects, init, goal.

parse_human_plan.system_prompt: You analyze a human plan against a symbolic model. Parse the plan for scenario_A, align each step with the action schema, and compute per-step required preconditions against the running state, expected add and delete effects, and causal links. Report any open preconditions, conflicts, and suggested repairs. Do not emit PDDL.
parse_human_plan.prompt: Your name is plan_analyst. Use the public action descriptions and the scenario_A plan from environment.scenarios along with the symbolic specification to produce a machine-readable analysis containing: steps, preconditions_satisfied, open_preconditions, effects_applied, causal_links, conflicts, and suggested_repairs. Do not modify the plan order.

audit.system_prompt: You audit temporal and causal consistency. Verify that action schemas, scenario initial states, goals, and plan analysis are mutually consistent. Remove bookkeeping shortcuts such as quota tokens or post-hoc penalties and flag any such constructs if found. Produce a brief audit report with verified invariants, issues, and recommended clarifications for orchestrator. Do not emit PDDL.
audit.prompt: Your name is temporal_auditor. Cross-check symbolic_spec, instances_spec, and plan_a_parse. Confirm predicate naming, arities, and action effects; verify that scenario_A plan steps are causally supported or identify exact violations; state whether scenario_B appears solvable under the same model. Output a compact audit report with items: invariants, inconsistencies, clarifications, and risk_notes.

compile_pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert with multi-agent PDDL problems. Produce the final PDDL domain and a single PDDL problem for scenario_B only. Always enclose the domain between <domain></domain> and the problem between <problem></problem>. Ensure FastDownward compatibility (use :strips and optionally :typing if you add types; avoid quantifiers and derived predicates). Keep the exact action names and effects: paltry, sip, clip, wretched, memory, tightfisted. Ensure all objects are declared and all initial facts and goals are grounded and consistent.
compile_pddl.prompt: Integrate the symbolic_spec, instances_spec, and audit_report to produce a correct PDDL domain and one PDDL problem for scenario_B. Do not alter action semantics. Declare predicates: hand, cats, texture, vase, next, sneeze, spring, stupendous, collect. Include all objects listed in scenario_B. The problem goal is: next object_12 object_10, next object_13 object_10, next object_14 object_9. Enclose the results in the required tags and target FastDownward.
